Description: Scaraboid in glazed composition; back in form of Black African head, with hair represented by squares and facial features crudely cut out; underside inscribed with incised hieroglyphs arranged horizontally, with from left to right Maat feather, walking goose (or duck?) and sun-disc; no glaze (lost or not applied?); in black paste; quite eroded surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Naukratis provided various scarabs and scaraboids, in glazed composition, Egyptian blue and steatite with a similar inscription (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 83-85; Gorton 1996, 102-103, type XXVIII B, subtype B24-36, see especially B36 for this piece). With this scaraboid made of coloured paste, it would probably fit best in her group XXXIII A. Depending on the identification of the bird, a goose or a duck, its translation can be either a cryptographic reading of the name of Amun-Ra, the goose being a sacred animal to him, or the motto 'Shu, son of Ra' (for both readings: Magnarini 2004, 317, 10.55). Drioton translated this trigram by Amun (Drioton 1957, 17, no. 5). Petrie listed different variants with a goose or a duck as a central motif (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 83-88, esp. the type 83 for this piece). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Magnarini, F. 2004. Catalogo ragionato di una collezione di Scarabeo-Sigillo Egizi, BAR International Series 1241.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 83) (wrong type)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 102, Type XXVIII B36)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.22) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musée du Louvre, Paris
